preface.title: Preface
preface.para: Apache Isis is designed to allow programmers rapidly develop domain-driven applications following the Naked Objects pattern. It is made up of a core framework plus a number of alternate implementations, and supports various viewers and object stores. Apache Isis is hosted at the Apache Foundation, and is licensed under Apache Software License v2.
If all you are interested in is just using Isis, then please refer to where to start? page on the Isis site. This will explain how to get going using a Maven archetype.
This guide though, is for those who want to go a little deeper. It breaks into three parts:

listitem.para: the first part is for those just wanting to build either Apache Isis or its site+documentation from source, without necessarily contributing any changes back to the projects;

the second part is for those who are intending to contribute changes back. It deals with such matters as setting up the standard development environment, writing documentation and site documentation; and releasing Isis.
the third part covers the release process, and is for those contributors who want to be able to make Isis releases (snapshot or formal Apache releases)

preface.para: Note that some of this material also appears, in different form, on the Apache Isis wiki:

The intent is for this guide to be definitive, but you may find that the wiki may have slightly more up-to-date (or indeed less-out-of-date) information. At any rate, it's worth checking the wiki out too...

partintro.para: This part of the contributors guide describes how to build Apache Isis from source, for example, just to get a better understanding of how the project works, or because your organization requires any open source projects to be re-built in-house.
This part of the guide also covers how to build Isis' site and documentation (along with prerequisite software that needs to be installed prior to doing this).
If you are looking to contribute to Apache Isis itself, the information in this part of the guide does still apply, but see also for much more information.

chapter.title: Prerequisite Software

abstract.para: The software needed to build Apache Isis.

chapter.para: This chapter describes the prerequisite software needed to build Apache Isis modules, and its site and documentation.

sect1.title: Command Line Software
sect1.para: Install the following software (you may well already have these installed):

listitem.para: a Subversion client (the svn executable)
and setup the JAVA_HOME environment variable;
Maven 2.2.1,
and setup the MAVEN_HOME environment variable.
Highly recommended is to also setup the MAVEN_OPTS environment variable, to:

note.para: At the time of writing, Maven 3.0 was not currently supported; see ISIS-11.

sect1.para: Finally, add Subversion's svn executable and Maven's mvn executable to your PATH environment variable.

sect1.title: IDE
sect1.para: Apache Isis is built using Maven, so it isn't strictly necessary to use an IDE. However, we do strongly recommend it.
All of the main IDEs provide Maven support: NetBeans and IntelliJ "natively", while Eclipse provides support through both the m2eclipse or the q4e plugins.
Install each of these from their respective update sites.

sect3.title: Base Install
sect3.para: Install a recent version of Eclipse (eg 3.5 or 3.6). The standard Java edition is sufficient, but you can install the JEE enterprise edition if you wish.
As a minimum, Eclipse requires the subclipse and m2eclipse plugins. These should be installed next.

sect3.title: Subclipse
sect3.para: The subclipse plugin provides Subversion support, and can be installed from its update site.

sect3.title: m2eclipse
sect3.para: Normally Eclipse uses its own .project and .classpath files to (respectively) define the layout of the project and the classpath for a project. With Maven however this same information is available in the pom.xml.

What the m2eclipse plugin does is generate the .project and .classpath files on-the-fly, and uses Eclipse's own "Classpath Container" to reference Maven modules in the local repository. m2eclipse will also download any referenced modules from remote repositories into the local repository.
m2eclipse can be installed from its update site.
Once installed, we recommend that you point m2eclipse back to your local Maven installation, using Windows > Preferences > Maven > Installations:

sect3.title: Other Plugins
sect3.para: There are many other plugins that you can install with Eclipse. You might want to check out:

listitem.para: EasyShell, to provide easy integration with the operating system shell and command line.
Soyatec, for a free (or commercial) UML/code live synchronization (a la the venerable TogetherJ).
To install the free edition, it is necessary to install the GMF at the same time (see this forum posting).

Key bindings for the EasyShell commands can be set up using Windows > Preferences > General > Keys:
In addition, if you are also a contributor to Isis, then there are some additional plugins (FindBugs, CheckStyle, PMD) that should be installed for enforcing coding standards; see .

sect3.title: Templates
sect3.para: Apache Isis provides a number of code templates which will reduce the typing when applying standard patterns.

row.entry: for writing Isis domain objects, eg properties, collections, actions etc.
for writing unit tests that use JMock2, eg mockery, context etc

sect3.para: These can be downloaded from the Isis website, and installed using Windows > Preferences > Java > Editor > Templates:

sect2.title: Other IDEs
sect2.para: All of the committers for Isis use the Eclipse IDE with the m2eclipse plugin, so the instructions provided in this guide reflect our own experience. However, if you use one of the other IDEs, please feel free to contribute patches to this documentation to explain the setup, and we'll add in your words of wisdom here.

chapter.title: Building Isis from Source

abstract.para: How to build Isis' code modules (not site and docs) from source.

chapter.para: Isis is built using Maven, so you should then be able to get going using a simple mvn clean install. However, there is a little more to it than that, because we do have a number of profiles which allow the build to be tailored in various ways.

sect1.title: Maven Profiles
sect1.para: The Maven profiles that customize the build are activated by setting properties, where the property name determines the means by which the build is customized. They are:

listitem.para: This is the default, so can be omitted if no other -D properties are specified.
Using -D modules=standard will build the applib, core, defaults, alternatives and viewer modules
Using -D modules=all will build the applib, core, defaults, alternatives, viewer, support, release, examples and site-skin modules
skin or applib or core or defaults or alternatives or viewer or support or release or examples
Using -D modules=... for any of the above will build just the corresponding module
This is the default, so can be omitted if no other -D properties are specified.

Using -D build=standard when run under mvn clean install will perform the standard plugins for the Maven 'default' lifecycle, and will also run the enforcer, eclipse, source, jar and pdf plugins. See /project/build/plugins in the parent pom.xml for an up-to-date list.
This will perform a full build, which basically means to also run a number of additional plugins.

Using -D build=full runs all the plugins for standard, along with the javadoc plugin (is 'jar' goal). See /project/profiles/profile[id='build-full']/build/plugins in the parent pom.xml for an up-to-date list.

sect1.para: The -D modules=xxx and -D build=yyy profiles are pretty much orthogonal; any set of modules can be built with either build profile. The one exception minor exception is that the release module (and hence any profile that references it) cannot be built using -D build=full.

sect1.title: Smoke Test
sect1.para: Once you've build the source code, you might want to run a smoke test.

The best way to do this is to use the quick start archetype. How to do this is documented on the website; however we want to run the archetype in a slightly different form, specifying the local catalog (ie to pick up the modules just built):

chapter.title: Building Site and Documentation

abstract.para: How to build Isis' site and documentation from source.

chapter.para: In the same way that Isis code modules are built using mvn clean install (see ), so too can its site and documentation be built using mvn site-deploy. Again though, there is a little more to it than that, because we do have a number of profiles which allow the build to be tailored in various ways. There is also some prerequisite software that must be installed.

sect1.title: Prerequisites (JIMI Jar File)
sect1.para: Generally speaking all Maven artifacts are automatically downloads from the Maven central repo. However, some artifacts must be manually installed or built, either because they haven't been formally released or because there are licensing restrictions preventing them from being hosted in the repository. These must therefore be downloaded and manually installed into your local repository (~/.m2/repository) .
Apache Isis currently use the JIMI jar to generate documentation. Therefore:

listitem.para: From the Jimi page, download the jimi1_0.zip file, and unzip.
Within the unzipped files, you'll find the JimiProClasses.zip file. This is the JAR that needs to be installed. Make a note of its location.
Install into your local Maven repository using:
listitem.screen: mvn install:install-file \ -D groupId=com.java \ -D artifactId=jimi \ -D version=1.0 \ -D packaging=jar \ -D file=/path/to/JimiProClasses.zip

sect1.title: Maven Profiles
sect1.para: The Maven profiles customize the build are activated by setting properties, where the property name determines the means by which the build is customized.
They are:

listitem.para: Using -D modules=skin will build just the skin module
This is the default, so can be omitted if no other -D properties are specified.
Using -D modules=standard will build all modules.
skin or applib or core or runtimes or progmodels or security or viewer or support.
Using -D modules=... for any of the above will build just the corresponding module

Using -D site=standard when run under mvn site-deploy will perform the standard plugins for the Maven 'site' lifecycle, and will also run the docbkx plugin (where relevant) in order to build the DocBook documentation. See /project/build/plugins in the parent pom.xmlfor an up-to-date list (note the binding to the 'site' phase).
This will perform a full build, which basically means to also run a number of additional reporting plugins.

Using -D site=full in addition runs all the reporting plugins runs all the plugins for standard, along with the surefire-report, project-info-reports, cobertura, checkstyle, pmd, findbugs, javancss, jdepend, jxr, taglist, javadoc.
See /project/profiles/profile[id='site-full']/reporting/plugins in the parent pom.xml for an up-to-date list.
Using -D deploy=local will deploy the site to /tmp/m2-sites/isis, where you can check it
At the time of writing the profile for remote deployment to Apache's staging server (-D deploy=remote) had not been finalized.

sect1.para: The -D modules=xxx and -D site=yyy profiles are pretty much orthogonal; any set of modules can be built with either build profile. The one exception minor exception is that the release module (and hence any profile that references it) cannot be built using -D site=full.

sect1.title: Typical Use Cases
sect1.para: Most of the time you'll find yourself running just one of a small number of commands. This section lists the typical use cases.

warning.para: The first time you run these, you'll need to omit the -o (offline) flag in order to download plugins and dependencies. Thereafter though the -os flag is strongly recommended!

Full build of site and documentation
Quick build all code and documentation

partintro.para: If you are looking to contribute to Apache Isis, then this part of the guide offers guidance on how to contribute changes. It builds on the first part, , and assumes that you have installed any prerequisite software.

Note that in order to gain commit writes to Apache Software Foundation projects, you must be voted in as a committer by the existing community. In order for that to happen, you will need to have shown demonstrated an ongoing and active interest. The easiest way to do this is to participate in discussions on the mailing list, to file or comment on JIRA tickets (bugs/defects), and to provide patches to bugs/defects by way of attaching to the relevant JIRA tickets.

chapter.title: Coding Standards Principles

abstract.para: This chapter describes the principles of the main coding standards adopted within the Isis codebase. The enforcement of these coding standards is through plugins to both the IDE and Maven,

chapter.para: This chapter describes the principles of the main coding standards adopted within the Isis codebase. The enforcement of these coding standards is through plugins to both the IDE and Maven, see .

warning.para: The style of framework code has developed over the lifetime of the project, so you won't find that all code satisfies the principles laid out here. We expect to address this piecemeal, incrementally moving towards these principles over time. The use of tools and plugins should help.

sect1.title: Code Formatting
sect1.para: A code formatting conventions adopted are those in use within a number of other Apache projects. Some of the more important standards are:

listitem.para: Indentation is achieved using spaces, not tabs; there should be no tabs, except where needed in quoted strings
Each level of indentation is 4 characters
Code lines are wrapped at 120 characters, with a 4 space indentation for wrapped lines
Statements should only be wrapped when too long for the line
Braces ({}) start on the same line as their controlling statement and end, indented to the same level as the starting line, on a new line
One blank line between package statement and imports
One blank lines between imports and class/interface declaration
One blank line between each method declaration, and blocks of field etc

sect1.para: See for details on configuring the Eclipse code formatter for these standards.

listitem.para: All names appearing in code should be written in English and be full words.
Abbreviations should be avoided unless they are well known and unambiguous.
Complementary names should be used for complementary concepts, showing that they are related.
For example: start/stop; next/previous; begin/end, open/close, show/hide.
all package names should be in lower case
where an artifact is acting as an aggregator module:
its groupId should be "one up" from the group it manages
its artifactId should be plural and be the same as the last element of the groupId it is aggregating for
For example, using the groupId:artifactId notation:
org.apache.isis.runtimes.dflt:objectstores is the aggregator for the "objectstores" group.
Child modules within this group would include org.apache.isis.runtimes.dflt.objectstores:sql and org.apache.isis.runtimes.dflt.objectstores:xml.
the package name should be the concatenation of the group Id and the artifact Id
For example, all packages in the org.apache.isis.runtimes.dflt.objectstores:xml module should reside in the org.apache.isis.runtimes.dflt.objectstores.xml package.
all package names should be lower case
Interfaces should not have an 'I' placed in front of it.
Implemenations should not have an "Impl" suffix. Instead identify the implementation technology; eg AuthenticationManagerLdap.
If there really is no good suffix, use "Default" rather than "Impl"; eg ProgrammingModelDefault.
Method names should be verbs and written in mixed case starting with lower case; eg isActionStatic(), prepare().
Accessor and mutator method names should be prefixed with get and set; eg getActionName(), setDelay(...).
Boolean variable and accessor method names should be prefixed with is, can, has or should; eg isDirty(), canSave(...).
Variable names must be in mixed case starting with lower case (never an underscore). Variables should have full sensible name, reflecting their purpose; eg count, target, previousOid.
Short variable names should only be used within small blocks of codes or short method.
Short variable names should never be used for parameter names

sect2.title: Constant Naming
sect2.para: Constants' names should be all uppercase with an underscore between words.

listitem.para: Use final variables where possible
All final parameters always
DO NOT check in commented-out code
use the repository to revert to previous versions
Go for "Clean Code" (see Robert Martin's book):
Methods should typically be no more than 10 lines long
Try to ensure methods are either commands or queries (no side-effects)
Think and aim for immutability if possible
Unless there is a clash of class names, fully qualified names should not be used in the code
Add TODO, REVIEW, FIXME tasks to code wherever work is to be done on the code that you are not going to do now
Do not overuse comments - they go out-of-sync with the code, causing confusion.
Comments should be used explaining the WHY
Comments should not be used for explaining the WHAT - that should be reflected in the method name
Comments should not be used for explaining the HOW - read the body of the method instead
Comments should not be used for explaining the WHO or the WHEN - that's what Subversion is for
Don't introduce an explanatory comment in the middle of a method; instead, extract out the block as a method instead
Comments should not contain any JavaDoc tags that are not complete.
For example, remove @param markers if they don't add any information over and above the name of the parameter.

sect2.title: Imports

listitem.para: Imports should be grouped by major type, with a blank line between each.
The order should be: java, javax, com, org, org.apache.isis.
Classes, not packages, should be imported; don't use '*'
No un-needed imports should be left in the code

sect2.para: Eclipse's Source > Organize Imports can be used to organize imports. See for details on how to configure Eclipse to enforce the required order.

listitem.para: Use constants instead of fixed phrases, except for messages, debug information and the like.
For example:
Use constants instead of magic numbers.
For example:
Place public constants in a non-instantiable *Constants class for the package. This makes the constants easier to locate.
For example, a 'remoting' package might have a RemotingConstants class:

sect2.title: Member Order
sect2.para: Declarations within each class should follow the standard order:

listitem.para: Typed (inner classes etc)
Static field
Static initializers
Static methods
Initializers
Fields
Constructors
Methods

sect2.para: This order can be specified in the preferences under Java/Appearance/Members Sort Order, and the code can be ordered using the Source/Sort Members options.

sect2.title: Method Order
sect2.para: Methods should be grouped by responsibility, with comment blocks used to delineate different responsibilities:
By convention, methods which access the IsisContext or are injected should go at the end:
These should be non-static and protected so that they can be overridden in tests with a stub or mock if required.

sect1.title: License Notices
sect1.para: In common with all other Apache projects, the standard Apache license notice should be present at the top of every code file.

chapter.title: Coding Standards Enforcement

abstract.para: How we enforce coding standards (in Eclipse) for Apache Isis.

chapter.para: The Apache Isis community has standardized on using Eclipse as its preferred IDE. This chapter describes the main tools that are available to help enforce the coding standard principles described in .

sect1.title: Code Style Templates
sect1.para: All Apache projects are required to have a standard license comment at the top of every code file. Eclipse can be configured so that these licenses are automatically available in every new file.
Therefore, download the code style template config file and import using Windows > Preferences > Java > Code style > Code Templates:
Make sure that the "Automatically add comments for new methods and types" is selected. Now, when you create a new class using File > New > Class, the license comments will already be in place.

sect1.title: Code Style Formatter
sect1.para: Apache Isis has adopted a set of coding standards used by several other Apache projects, and compatible with our own principles. These projects have previously developed a configuration file for Eclipse's Code Style Formatter feature, meaning that the formatting can be applied easily.
Therefore, download the code style formatter config file and import using Windows > Preferences > Java > Code Style > Formatter:
To run the formatter, use Source > Format. Note that this can be done recursively, from a higher level package if required.
Alternatively, you can use Cleanup, (see ), which performs formatting and a number of other checks too.
A final option is to you configure formatting to be run automatically as a Save action (see ).

sect1.title: Code Style Cleanup
sect1.para: Apache Isis provides a configuration file for Eclipse's Code Style Cleanup feature. This defines a set of operations aimed at removing simple problems with the code, as well as running the formatter (see ).
Therefore, download the code style cleanup config file and import using Windows > Preferences > Java > Code Style > Cleanup:

screenshot.screeninfo: Configuring Eclipse's Java Code Style Cleanup

sect1.para: The cleanup wizard can be run on an adhoc basis using Source > Cleanup. Note that this can be done recursively, from a higher level package if required. For example:

sect1.title: Import Order
sect1.para: Our coding standard principles recommend a fixed import order. This can be configured using Eclipse's Code Style Organize Imports feature.
Therefore, download the code style organize imports config file and import using Windows > Preferences > Java > Code Style > Organize Imports:

The import order can be reorganized using Source > Organize Imports. Note that this can be done recursively, from a higher level package if required. It can also be defined to be run automatically as a Save Action, see .

sect1.title: Save Actions
sect1.para: While the formatter () and organize imports () can be run manually, it is also possible to run the formatter whenever code is saved.
To configure this, navigate to Windows > Preferences > Save > Actions and enable:

From the dialog it is also possible to automatically perform the same actions as the cleanup (the Configure button). However, it doesn't seem possible (as of Eclipse 3.6) to export/import these settings within a config file.
Our recommendation for now is just to enable the simple formatting on save and organize imports, and not waste time manually configuring any other actions on save too.

warning.para: We make the above recommendation slightly tentatively; reformatting all lines clearly could cause a lot of changes.

chapter.title: Code Quality

abstract.para: Using plugins such as Checkstyle and PMD to improve code quality.

chapter.para: As well as using the tools to enforce code standards, there are also numerous tools available to improve the overall code quality. As many projects do, Apache Isis uses these tools to improve the quality of its codebase.

The tools that we configure are intended to run in both the IDE (for immediate visibility to the contributor community) and within Maven (for visibility to the user community). There is some overlap between them.

listitem.para: the EclEmma plugin (for Eclipse), and Cobertura (for Maven) test coverage results
Eclipse's own compiler warnings configuration
the eclipse-cs plugin, for Checkstyle support
the PMD for eclipse plugin, for PMD support

chapter.para: In addition, we recommend that findBugs is installed into the IDE. However, findBugs is not part of the Maven build because it would flag violations that, to suppress, would require introducing a dependency on its associated library which is published under LGPL (not compatible with the ASF).
This chapter describes the configuration of some of these tools.

warning.para: This chapter is more of a statement-of-intent for the future, rather than reflecting the current status. Right now, if we run these tools with the config files that we've located/inherited, we will end up with an overwhelming number of issues. There is also some overlap between these config files, which still needs to be eliminated.
So, the plan is to pare down these config files to a bare minimum, and then slowly ratchet up the tests as we aim to improve the overall code quality going forward.
By all means go ahead and configure these plugins, but be aware that we have not - yet - fully configured them nor are tracking their outputs.

sect1.title: Code Coverage (Cobertura and Emma)
sect1.para: Code coverage of unit testing is provided using EclEmma for Eclipse and Cobertura for Maven. Although there is an Eclipse plugin for Cobertura, it has not been maintained and no longer runs on the latest versions of Eclipse. Conversely, although there is a Maven plugin for Emma, the Cobertura plugin gives reports that are more easily understood.

note.para: In fact, in the future we may move to JaCoCo, a new code coverage tool being developed by the originators of EclEmma. One of the benefits of JaCoCo is that the instrumentation is performed via a java:agent, ie on-the-fly. This would allow code coverage to be captured during integration tests, for example, without requiring a specific build.

sect2.title: Eclipse Plugin (Emma)
sect2.para: The EclEmma Eclipse plugin offers transparent code coverage directly within the Eclipse IDE. Rather than run the tests using Run > Run As > JUnit Test, instead use Coverage > Coverage As > JUnit Test. This will instrument the code and then provide a coverage view and highlights in the editor to show which code has been exercised.
The coverage view looks like:
The highlighted editor looks like:
Use the menu item on the Coverage View to select between manage the history of coverage runs (selecting none / deleting all removes the highlights on the editor).
To change what code is instrumented, use Run > Coverage ...

sect2.title: Maven Plugin (Cobertura)
sect2.para: The isis-parent POM automatically includes the Maven Cobertura plugin:
This plugin is not bound to any Maven lifecycle phase, and is not intended to be run other than as a report within mvn site. For more immediate feedback, use the Emma Eclipse plugin, above.

sect1.title: Compiler Warnings
sect1.para: Eclipse can be configured so that Java compiler warnings can be elevated to being fatal errors, or conversely moved down to ignored.

At the current time we do not configuration file for Eclipse, but we do intend to do this in the future. The plan will be to start with a relatively lax set of warnings (ie most set to ignore) in order that we can get 0 warnings in the build. Then we'll slowly start to elevate back up to warning, and use that as a way to improve the codebase piecemeal.

sect1.title: Checkstyle
sect1.para: Checkstyle is the first of three powerful tools (the others being PMD and FindBugs) for enforcing coding standards and detecting certain classes of likely errors. The checkstyle definition config file for Apache Isis is derived from Sun's standards, with a number of modifications.
Checkstyle integrates with both Maven and with Eclipse.

sect2.title: Eclipse Plugin
sect2.para: The eclipse-cs plugin allows Checkstyle violations to be flagged as warnings or errors within the Problems view of the Eclipse IDE. To associate eclipse-cs with the Checkstyle config file, use Windows > Preferences, and specify the config file as http://incubator.apache.org/isis/codequality/checkstyle.xml. Alternatively, the file is available locally in trunk/src/site/resources/codequality/checkstyle.xml.

para.remark: TODO: the screenshot is out of date

warning.para: According to eclipse-cs' documentation, it is meant to integrate with m2eclipse and transparently pick up any Maven configuration of mvn-checkstyle-plugin. This doesn't seem to work for me, though.

sect2.para: You may then need to enable CheckStyle for each project as required, using the context menu in Package Explorer. CheckStyle violations show up in the Problems view:

screenshot.screeninfo: Viewing CheckStyle violations in the Problems view

sect2.para: These violations are dynamic updated, so fixing any problem should automatically remove the violation from the problems view. A quick fix short cut (ctrl+1) is available for some of these.

sect2.title: Maven Plugin
sect2.para: The isis-parent POM automatically includes the Maven checkstyle plugin:

<properties> <checkstyle.configLocation> ${trunkBaseDir}/src/site/resources/codequality/checkstyle.xml </checkstyle.configLocation> </properties> <reporting> <plugins> <plugin> <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId> <artifactId>maven-checkstyle-plugin</artifactId> <version>2.6</version> <configuration> <configLocation>${checkstyle.configLocation}</configLocation> </configuration> </plugin> </plugins> </reporting>This plugin is not bound to any Maven lifecycle phase, and is not intended to be run other than as a report within mvn site. In particular, note that the configuration is only defined in the <reporting> section, so it isn't possible to run using mvn checkstyle:checkstyle. For more immediate feedback, use the Eclipse plugin, above.

sect1.title: PMD
sect1.para: PMD is another static analysis tool that - like FindBugs and Checkstyle - checks for problematic code (possible bugs, dead code, suboptimal code and so on). As for Checkstyle, Apache Isis defines a PMD config file, this one adapted from other projects within Apache.
PMD integrates with both Maven and with Eclipse.

sect2.title: Eclipse Plugin
sect2.para: The PMD for eclipse plugin allows PMD violations to be flagged as warnings or errors within the Problems view of the Eclipse IDE. The plugin also provides a custom "PMD" perspective which also lists all violations. To associate PMD for Eclipse with the PMD config file, use Windows > Preferences:

First, use "Clear All" to remove the default rule set. Then, use "Import rule set" and specify the pmd.xml file. Unlike the Checkstyle plugin, this must be a local file so must be referenced locally, from trunk/src/site/resources/codequality/pmd.xml.

Also unlike the Checkstyle plugin, PMD violations are not continually updated against the code (it is not implemented as an Eclipse builder). To perform a check, you must use the context menu in Package Explorer and then use PMD > Check Code with PMD. This will switch into the PMD perspective; the Violations view will indicate any code that needs attention:

screenshot.screeninfo: Viewing PMD violations in the Violations view

sect2.para: Alternatively, you can switch back to the Java view; any PMD violations show up in the Problems view:

screenshot.screeninfo: Viewing PMD violations in the Problems view

sect2.para: Once violations are fixed, the Check must be performed again to refresh both of these views.
Note, to prevent PMD from switching to its own perspective, use Windows > Preferences > PMD and then disable "Show PMD Perspective when checking code".

sect2.title: Maven Plugin
sect2.para: The isis-parent POM automatically includes the Maven PMD plugin:

As for Checkstyle, this plugin is not bound to any Maven lifecycle phase, and is not intended to be run other than as a report within mvn site. In particular, note that the configuration is only defined in the <reporting> section, so it isn't possible to run using mvn pmd:pmd. For more immediate feedback, use the Eclipse plugin, above.

sect1.title: FindBugs
sect1.para: FindBugs is a tool that - like CheckStyle and PMD - can be used to enforce coding standards and detecting certain classes of likely errors.
FindBugs does not (seem to) have a configuration file; it is just run against a codebase and reports all errors.

Although FindBugs integrates with both Maven and with Eclipse, we do not include it in the Maven build. This is because the companion library that is used to suppress certain types of warning is licensed under LGPL, which the ASF views as being incompatible with the ASF v2 license.
Nevertheless, we do recommend installing FindBugs for Eclipse.

sect2.title: Eclipse Plugin
sect2.para: The findbugs plugin allows FindBugs to be run against a single Eclipse project at a time, eg from the context menu:
If this finds any errors, then Bugs Found!
You can then switch to the findbugs perspective to review and fix the potential bugs:

screenshot.screeninfo: yViewing CheckStyle violations in the Problems view

sect2.para: If you want to suppress, rather than fix, the bug, you can annotate using the @edu.umd.cs.findbugs.annotations.SuppressWarnings annotion. For example:

chapter.title: Writing Documentation

abstract.para: This chapter provides some guidance on writing both DocBook and site (APT) documentation.

chapter.para: This chapter provides some guidance on writing both DocBook and site (APT) documentation, explaining what sort of content should go into each of these types, as well as the mechanics of actually writing these types of documents.
See for details on how to build the site documentation.
See and for details on how to write APT or DocBook documentation.

sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: Maven provides the ability to automatically create a website holding various reports, such as Checkstyle, PMD, test results and code coverage. At least as far as Apache Isis is concerned, the site created reflects the module hierarchy, with at least one single index.html page to introduce each module. The main site (corresponding to isis-parent) has rather more content, eg discussing the naked objects pattern.

This additional site content can be written in a number of formats, but the most straightforward is to use Maven's own APT format. APT here stands for "almost plain text"; it's basically a wiki-like syntax. The index.html for each file would typically correspond to index.apt file; the site content lives under src/site (relative to each module's pom.xml).

In addition, a number of the modules have formal documentation in the form of (all-in-one) user/programmer/developer guides. These are written in DocBook 4.5, so that they can be processed by the docbkx-maven-plugin and converted to either PDF or HTML. These guides can be found under src/docbkx (relative to the module's pom.xml).

sect1.title: Maven Modules
sect1.para: The following tables indicates which modules have DocBook guides, and which do not:

row.entry: Common classes for runtime implementations constructs
Common filters etc. for web-based viewers
Parent for security (authentication and authorization) implementations
Default runtime implementation, includes documentation on bttecode providers, default object store and default profile store
Parent for default runtime's object store implementations
Default (in-memory) object store; documentation included in default runtime's, see above
Parent for default runtime's profilte store implementations
Default (in-memory) profile store; documentation included in default runtime's, see above

sect1.para: In general, the principle is for the DocBook guide to be reasonably complete. The docbkx-maven-plugin is capable of transforming the guide into fully hyperlinked HTML, and the configuration within the pom.xml is such that this is published as part of the site. In addition (as already mentioned) the DocBook is also converted into PDF for those that prefer that form (eg to download and print out).

The APT site documentation therefore should be used to provide just enough of an overview so that a prospective user can understand what the particular module is for, and to provide signposting to the more detailed docbook guide where needed. Much of this signposting is taken care of already, being configured in the site menu.

chapter.title: APT Quick Start

abstract.para: Common use cases for writingy site documentation using APT.

chapter.para: As discussed in , Apache Isis uses Maven's APT (almost plain text) syntax for most of its site documentation. This chapter is a quick-start on using APT.

sect1.title: File Formats and Locations
sect1.para: When writing additional site content

listitem.para: documents go in src/site/xxx, where xxx is the file format.
For example APT documents live under src/site/apt.
images and other resources go in src/site/resources and are referenced relative to this directory.
For example images typically live under src/site/resources/images.

sect1.para: For example, src/site/apt/index.apt will correspond to index.html for the module.
Maven sites can include documentation in any of a number of file formats:

table.title: File formats supported by Maven site

sect1.para: Of these, APT is the lowest entry, and is the generally recommended format. APT reference is available online at http://maven.apache.org/doxia/references/apt-format.html, but the following are some of the main formatting tips.

sect1.title: Sections and Sub-sections
sect1.para: Sections are not indented, paragraphs are.
sect1.screen:
My section title (not indented).
My paragraph first line (indented by 2 spaces). There is no need for remaining sentences in the paragraph to be indented. A blank line terminates the paragraph.
sect1.para: Subsections can be defined using leading asterisks (*) to indicate the subsection level indents:
sect1.screen:
Section title
* Sub-section title
** Sub-sub-section title
*** Sub-sub-sub-section title

sect1.title: Fonts
sect1.para: In addition to regular font, we can specify italics, bold or monospaced:

sect1.title: Lists
sect1.para: List items are indented, and begin with an asterisk (*)
sect1.screen:
* List item 1.
* List item 2.
Paragraph contained in list item 2.
* Sub-list item 1.
* Sub-list item 2.
* List item 3.
sect1.para: To force the end of a list, use the [] pseudo-element:
sect1.screen:
* List item 3.
[]
This text is not in the list

sect1.title: Links and Figures
sect1.para: To create an external link, use:
sect1.screen: Link to {{http://www.pixware.fr}}. or Link to {{{http://www.pixware.fr}Pixware home page}}.
sect1.para: To create an internal link (to a page relative to this one), use:

warning.para: the "./" is required for internal links.

sect1.para: To create an anchor, use:
sect1.screen: {Anchor}. This text is anchored. and then Link to {{anchor}}. or Link to {{{anchor}showing alternate text}}
sect1.para: Figures are specified by

sect1.title: Code Blocks (verbatim text)
sect1.para: To quote a code block, use 3 dashes (---) before and after:
To put into a box, use a plus symbol (+--)

sect1.title: Other Code Elements
sect1.para: In addition to the above, APT supports tables, horizontal rules (===), page breaks, comments and special characters. See the Maven Doxia site for further details.

chapter.title: DocBook Quick Start

abstract.para: Common use cases for writing formal documentation using DocBook.

chapter.para: As discussed in , Apache Isis uses DocBook as its primary documentation format, each significant module providing its own guide which is then converted into both PDF and HTML forms.

DocBook is just XML, so you could edit the text with any text editor. However, you may find it easier to use an editor; and the we recommend here is from XMLMind. The personal edition is free for use on open source projects.
Below is a quick notes on using XmlMind.

sect1.title: Writing DocBook Guides (using XMLMind)
sect1.para: DocBook guides can be found in src/docbkx (relative to the module's pom.xml).

sect1.title: Creating a Document
sect1.para: Use File > New Document to create an DocBook document. This will create a v4.5 docbook:
The file should be saved under src/docbkx/guide.

Once the file has been created, change the DOCTYPE entry to reference DTDs stored locally. We use the svn:externals property to "symbolically link" 3 directories under trunk/src/docbkx/guide (dtd-4.5, images and style); these can therefore be referenced locally.
In addition, the standard Apache license comment is required.
Here's the boilerplate to copy-n-paste in:
sect1.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!-- Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more contributor license agreements. See the NOTICE file distributed with this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership. The ASF licenses this file to you under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at
http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. --> <!DOCTYPE book PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DocBook XML V4.5//EN" "file:./src/docbkx/dtd-4.5/docbookx.dtd">
<book> ... </book>
sect1.para: Note the DTD location, as file:./src/test/resources/dtd.

sect1.title: Loading a Document
sect1.para: To load an existing document, simply use File>Open. This will display the DocBook styled using the CSS. DocBook does allow the CSS to be customized; at the time of writing we have not done this for DocBook.

sect1.title: Navigating the Document
sect1.para: To navigate around, use up arrow, down arrow, pg up, pg down to move around.
It is also possible to navigate by opening up an alternative view, using View > Add to bring up a dialog:
For example, this is a view of the raw XML:
Alternatively it could be styled as a document structure:
This can then be used to navigate, collapsing sections if needed.

sect1.title: Knowing where you are
sect1.para: The position within the document is shown as a XPath like expression. If the unstyled view is open, then the current position is highlighted (even if the section is collapsed). In the styled view the current cursor position is shown just as in a regular word processor.

sect1.title: Selecting Content (eg to delete/move, or prior to adding new content)s
sect1.para: The XMLMind editor understands the structure of DocBook documents, and will only let you enter content where it is valid to do so. What you can do (in terms of edits) therefore depends on where you are in the document.
Use Select > Select Parent (ctrl+up) to successively select larger segments of the document; and Select > Select Child (ctrl+down) to selects smaller segments.

sect2.title: Adding New Paragraphs
sect2.para: To modify the content in a paragraph, just start writing! Hitting enter will start a new paragraph; delete will join two paragraphs together. Behind the scenes the <para> elements are added.

sect2.title: Formatting Existing Paragraphs
sect2.para: Using Edit > Insert (ctrl+I) within a paragraph will only bring up elements that are valid within that paragraph, such as emphasis:

That said, for adding tags within a paragraph (such as emboldening or emphasis), it is generally easier to write the words and then use Edit > Convert (wrap). First, highlight the words by holding shift and then navigating as usual (eg shift+left, shift+right). Then, use Edit>Convert(wrap) to add the emphasis.

sect2.title: Adding a new heading (sect1, sect2) etc
sect2.para: In general, use Edit > Insert After (ctrl+J) after to add new content after the current location, and Edit > Insert Before (ctrl+H) to insert before. This will bring up a list of valid elements in the top right:

Note that it isn't possible to add a new subsection in the middle of existing paragraphs; as the screenshot below shows, attempting to add a section "sect3" under this paragraph would not be allowed, for example:
Instead, go to last paragraph (eg like this one) and add the subsection there. Then cut-and-paste the content around as required.

sect2.title: Adding lists
sect2.para: Adding lists are added as for any element: use ctrl+J and then select itemizedlist (unordered list) or <orderedlist>. Youll get the first listitem for free. Create new list items by selecting the current list item (ctrl+up as far as required) then use ctrl+J.
If you want to terminate the list, then select the current list (ctrl+up), then ctrl+J and select para for next paragraph.

sect2.title: Adding Images
sect2.para: Images should be saved as .png files, under the images subdirectory (relative the directory holding xxx-guide.xml).

Images should be embedded into the documentation using either a mediaobject/imageobject/imagedata tag or a screenshot/mediaobject/imageobject/imagedata tag. In XMLMind, use Edit>Insert and select screenshot:
The outer imagedata tag should have an appropriate scale attribute; a value of 50 (note: not 50%) works reasonably well:

sect2.title: Adding and Altering Tables
sect2.para: Use Edit > Insert After (or Edit > Insert Before), and then select one of the table elements:

listitem.para: to include a header column (on the left hand side)
to include a header row
to include a header row and column

sect2.para: This will create a 2x2 table body with a header row and/or column if requested. Then use DocBook > Column > Insert or DocBook > Row > Insert to adjust the number of columns and rows as required.
To adjust the width of columns, select the first row and then use Edit>Insert before to insert <colspec> elements.
It's also possible to merge cells using DocBook>Cell>Increment ... Span

sect1.title: Deleting Content
sect1.para: To delete content, select the content first (ctrl+up / ctrl+down), then Edit > Delete (ctrl+K).
In general you shouldnt need to use the Edit > Force Deletion; instead try adjusting the range being selected if Edit > Delete isnt enabled.

sect1.title: Moving Content
sect1.para: Select the content you want using ctrl+up. If necessary extend the selection using Select > Extend Selection to Following Sibling or Select > Extend Selection to Preceding Sibling.

Use Edit > Cut to cut, and then Edit > Paste After or Edit > Paste Before to paste wherever. If these are greyed out, bear in mind that XmlMind wont let you paste in content where it would be invalid. If necessary, adjust the selection until they become enabled.

partintro.para: This part of the guide describes the release process for Apache Isis, in particular as it applies to the requirements of the Apache Software Foundation. It consists of:

listitem.para: an overview of the release process (see )
the detailed steps for performing a snapshot release (see )
the detailed steps for performing a formal release (see )

chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: The following diagram summarizes the various stages involved in building and releasing Apache Isis.
The steps are:

listitem.para: check out code using svn checkout (see ).
make changes, implements features, fixes bugs. These are installed, in the normal way, to local repo using mvn install.
when the codebase is ready for a snapshot release, manually deploy the snapshot into the Apache snapshot repo. This is discussed further in .
In addition, the snapshot version of the site may be deployed to the website. This is discussed further in .
when the codebase is ready for a formal release (-RCn), the contributor uses mvn release:prepare to produce the release artifacts. This goal:
update the POMs from x.x.x-SNAPSHOT-incubating to x.x.x-RCn-incubating
builds and verifies the codebase
commits the changes
creates a tag copy
updates the POMs for the next iteration, ie from x.x.x-RCn-incubating to x.x.y-incubating-SNAPSHOT
On the local computer the local repo (~/.m2/repository) will have signed versions of release (x.x.x) versions of all modules, and in trunk there will also be a signed zip of the source. See .
the signed version of the source is uploaded to the contributors home directory ready for voting. See .
the signed versions of the Maven binaries are deployed to the Apache staging directory ready for voting. Again, see .
the release is voted on by the community.
If the vote is rejected, then fixes are made and then the above steps (2 through 7) are performed again with the next release candidate.
If the vote is accepted, then the above steps (2 through 7) are performed again, but without the -RCn suffix
While in the incubator a vote must also be performed by the Incubator PMC (ie on mailto:incubator@apache.org). It is permissible to perform these in parallel if required. See
once the vote is passed, the source release should be copied/moved to the "dist" folder, where it will be mirrored. It can also be referenced as a download at this point. See
once the vote is passed, the binary release should be promoted from the staging repository to release repository (again, see ), after which...
... it will be automatically be replicated up to Maven central repo
Finally, the website should be deployed manually. See .

chapter.para: The following chapters provide detail on the above steps.

chapter.title: Snapshot Release
chapter.para: This chapter describes the steps that make up deploying a snapshot release.

As you'll see if you compare them with the steps required to make a formal release (see ), they are significantly less arduous. This is because the legal status of a snapshot release does NOT constitute an actual release of the ASF; it is merely provided as a convenience for users.

sect1.title: Contributor Prerequisites
sect1.para: The only prerequistes for performing a release is that the contributor has configured their environment. This involves updating your settings.xml file:
sect1.programlisting: <settings> <servers> <!-- To publish a snapshot of some part of Maven --> <server> <id>apache.snapshots.https</id> <username>xxx</username> <password>yyy</password> </server> ... </servers> ... </settings>
sect1.para: where 'xxx' and 'yyy' constitute your apache LDAP username and password.
This information is as documented in the ASF documentation.

note.para: It is also possible to configure to use .ssh secure keys, and thereby avoid hardcoding your Apache LDAP password into your .m2/settings.xml file. A description of how to do this can be found, for example, here.

sect2.title: Sanity Check
sect2.para: Before deploying the snapshot, perform a quick sanity check:

listitem.para: builds ok (mvn clean install)
archetype runs ok (-D archetypeCatalog=local)
app generated from the archetype runs ok

sect2.title: Deploy All Modules
sect2.para: Deploy all modules using:
sect2.programlisting: mvn -D deploy=snapshot deploy
sect2.para: This will deploy all the modules that make up a release, including the archetype.
To confirm that they are present, browse to the Nexus repository manager https://repository.apache.org and search for "isis".
Be warned: this is liable will take a long time.

sect2.title: Update archetype-catalog.xml (if required)
sect2.para: The Isis site comes with its own archetype-catalog.xml so that the quickstart archetype can be used from the snapshot repository by those who want to use the "latest-and-greatest". This file lives in .../trunk/src/main/site/resources, and looks something like:
sect2.programlisting: <archetype-catalog> <archetypes> <archetype> <groupId>org.apache.isis.support</groupId> <artifactId>quickstart-archetype</artifactId> <version>x.x.x-incubating-SNAPSHOT</version> <repository>http://repository.apache.org/content/groups/snapshots-group/</repository> <description>Isis Quickstart Archetype</description> </archetype> ... </archetypes> </archetype-catalog>
sect2.para: Where x.x.x-incubating-SNAPSHOT is the current release. It may also have entries for previous SNAPSHOT releases.
If it missing an entry for the current snapshot, then update it and commit.

sect2.title: Build the site
sect2.para: Next, build the site, as per .
This should generate the current site in /tmp/m2-sites/isis.

sect2.title: Upload the site
sect2.para: Finally, upload the site (as a ZIP) to your local account on people.apache.org:

listitem.para: cd /tmp/m2-sites
zip up isis to isis.zip
scp the isis.zip to people.apache.org/~
login to people.apache.org using ssh:
where xxxxxxx is your apache user Id
unzip isis.zip
This should leave you with the same directory, isis, as was previously in /tmp/m2-sites.

sect2.para: Then, copy the exploded ZIP into /www/incubator.apache.org:

listitem.para: Switch to the destination directory:
Move the previous site to one side:
where yyyymmdd is the date that the previous version was uploaded
move the new site into the distribution location:
mv ~/isis isis
make the new site readable by all:
listitem.programlisting: chmod -R g+w isis chgrp -R incubator isis for a in `find isis -type d -print` ; do chmod g+s $a ; done

chapter.title: Formal Release

abstract.para: This chapter describes the steps that make up a formal release.

chapter.para: Before starting off the release process it is essential to gain consensus on the isis-dev mailing list that this is the right time for a release and to agree its content. Allow at least a week for this discussion.

Once agreed, the formal release can begin. There are a number of prerequisites to the release, in terms of (a) the codebase itself, (b) the community process, and (c) the contributor acting as release manager and performing the release. There are then the actual steps required to perform the release (as per the diagram in ). This chapter discusses all of these things.

sect1.title: Code Prerequisites
sect1.para: Before making any formal release, there are a number of prerequisites that should always be checked.

sect2.title: Sanity check
sect2.para: Before deploying the snapshot, perform a quick sanity check:

listitem.para: builds ok (mvn clean install)
site builds ok (mvn site-deploy -D deploy=local -D site=full)
archetype is up-to-date
archetype runs ok (-D archetypeCatalog=local)
app generated from the archetype runs ok

sect2.title: Code Cleanup / Formatting
sect2.para: Make sure that all source code has been cleaned up and formatted according to the Isis and ASF conventions:

listitem.para: code formatting should be checked as per ;
imports should be organized as per ;
code cleanup should be performed as per . (this performs both code formatting and organizing imports)

sect2.para: Optionally, you might also want to run and address warnings from:

listitem.para: checkstyle, as per ;
PMD, as per ;
findbugs, as per .

sect2.title: License Notice (RAT Tool)
sect2.para: The Apache Release Audit Tool (RAT) is designed to perform a number of basic checks, most signifcant being missing copyright header files.

In theory it can be run from Maven (mvn rat:check), with the maven-rat-plugin being inherited from the Apache parent POM. However, although the plugin is configured in the Isis parent POM to exclude certain files (eg .java.hsp project files for Structure101). However, unfortunately the plugin seems to ignore any configured exclusions, making this method of performing a check somewhat useless.
Instead, the tool can be run from the command-line; a JAR binary of the tool has been checked into the Apache Isis codebase.
First, clean up any generated artifacts:
sect2.programlisting: mvn clean
sect2.para: Then, run the tool using:
sect2.programlisting: java -jar apache-rat-0.8-SNAPSHOT.jar \ -d . --exclude \ resources.txt site.vm \ *.project *.classpath *.launch *.importorder \ *.java.hsp \ *.ucd *.ucls \ *-LICENSE.txt \ fop-cust.xsl html-cust.xsl *.ent *.dtd *.pdn catalog.xml *.mod usage.txt screen.css docbook.cat \ org.apache.isis.viewer.wicket.ui.ComponentFactory \ fixture-data test.data example.ldif slapd.conf \ .plxarc MANIFEST.MF \ .log \ >/tmp/rat.txt
sect2.para: where:

listitem.para: resources.txt, site.vm are resources to do with site generation
.project, .classpath, .launch and .importorder are Eclipse IDE project files
.java.hsp are the Structure101 project files
.ucd and .ucls are Soyatec (UML plugin) project files
-LICENSE.txt are required license files for certain third party dependencies
fop-cust.xsl html-cust.xsl *.ent *.dtd *.pdn catalog.xml *.mod usage.txt screen.css docbook.cat are files related to DocBook generation
org.apache.isis.viewer.wicket.ui.ComponentFactory is a manifest file required for dynamic classloading
fixture-data test.data example.ldif slapd.conf are test resource files
.plxarc and MANIFEST.MF are artifacts generated by various Maven goals
.log are any generated log files

sect2.para: Then, review any missing license notes using:
sect2.programlisting: cat /tmp/rat.txt \ | grep '^ !???' \ | grep -v "tests-common/.*\.xml" \ | grep -v "tests-common/.*/tests\..*" \ | grep -v "tests-common/.*\.xml" \ | grep -v "tests/.*\.xml"
sect2.para: where:

listitem.para: !??? is used to identify those files that are missing license notes
tests-common/* and tests/* ignores certain test files

sect2.para: Investigate and fix any reported violations.

sect2.title: Missing License Check
sect2.para: Although Apache Isis has no dependencies which have incompatible licenses, the POMs for these dependencies (in the Maven central repo) do not necessarily contain the required license information. This results in the META-INF/DEPENDENCIES file and generated Maven site listing dependencies as being "unknown".

Fortunately, Maven allows the missing information to be provided by configuring the maven-remote-resources-plugin. This is stored in the src/main/appended-resources/supplemental-models.xml file in the parent [oai:isis-parent] module.
To capture the missing license information, use:
sect2.programlisting: mvn license:download-licenses groovy checkmissinglicenses.groovy
sect2.para: This Maven plugin creates a license.xml file in the target/generated-resources/ directory of each module.
Then, run the Isis script:
sect2.programlisting: groovy checkmissinglicenses.groovy
sect2.para: This searches for all licenses.xml files, and compares them against the contents of the supplemental-models.xml file. For example, the output could be something like:
sect2.programlisting:
licenses to add to supplemental-models.xml:
[org.slf4j, slf4j-api, 1.5.7] [org.codehaus.groovy, groovy-all, 1.7.2]
licenses to remove from supplemental-models.xml (are spurious):
[org.slf4j, slf4j-api, 1.5.2]
sect2.para: If any missing entries are listed or are spurious, then update supplemental-models.xml and try again.

sect2.title: Close all JIRA tickets for the release
sect2.para: All JIRA tickets for the release should be closed, or moved to future releases if not yet addressed.

sect2.title: Generate Release Notes
sect2.para: Each release should a release note page called release-x.x.x.html, in src/site/resources (in [oai:isis-parent]). This is linked to from the download page (src/site/apt/downloads.apt.vm); the download page should not need updating.

The release notes can be generated using JIRA, using the procedure documented here. If any of the tickets closed are tasks/subtasks, then please edit the contents of the file to associate them back together again.

sect2.title: Update STATUS file
sect2.para: The trunk holds a STATUS file which is a brief summary of the current status of the project. Update this file prior to cutting the release.

sect1.title: Contributor (Release Manager) Prerequisites
sect1.para: In order that a contributor can make a release it is necessary for them to have generated a key and had that key recognized by other members of the ASF.
For background information on this topic, see the release signing page and the openpgp page on the Apache wiki.

sect2.title: Install and Configure gpg
sect2.para: Download and install GnuPG (gpg), version 1.4.10 or higher.
Then, edit ~/.gnupg/gpg.conf (on Windows, the file to edit is C:\Users\xxx\AppData\Roaming\gnupg\gpg.conf) so that the default is to generate a strong key:

sect2.title: Key Generation
sect2.para: The ASF requires that keys are signed with a key (or subkey) based on RSA 4096 bits. To do this:
sect2.programlisting:
$ gpg --gen-key gpg (GnuPG) 1.4.11; Copyright (C) 2010 Free Software Foundation, Inc. This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it. There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.
Please select what kind of key you want: (1) RSA and RSA (default) (2) DSA and Elgamal (3) DSA (sign only) (4) RSA (sign only) Your selection?
sect2.para: Specify RSA key:
sect2.programlisting:
Your selection? 1
RSA keys may be between 1024 and 4096 bits long. What keysize do you want? (2048)
sect2.para: Specify key length as 4096 bits:
sect2.programlisting:
What keysize do you want? (2048) 4096 Requested keysize is 4096 bits
Please specify how long the key should be valid. 0 = key does not expire <n> = key expires in n days <n>w = key expires in n weeks <n>m = key expires in n months <n>y = key expires in n years Key is valid for? (0)
sect2.para: Specify key as non-expiring:

sect2.title: Publish Key
sect2.para: It is also necessary to publish your key. There are several places where this should be done. In most cases, you'll need the "armored" " (ie ASCII) representation of your key. This can be generated using:
sect2.programlisting: $ gpg --armor --export nnnnnnnn > nnnnnnnn.asc
sect2.para: where nnnnnnnn is the id of your public key.
You'll also need the fingerprint of your key. This can be generated using:
sect2.programlisting: $ gpg --fingerprint nnnnnnnn
sect2.para: The output from this command includes a line beginning "Key fingerprint", followed by a (space delimited) 40 character hexadecimal fingerprint. The last 8 characters should be the same as the key id (nnnnnnnn).

sect3.title: Publish to your Apache home directory
sect3.para: The armored representation of your public key should be uploaded to your home directory on people.apache.org, and renamed as .pgpkey. Make sure this is readable by all.

sect2.title: Attend Key Signing Party (Apache web of trust)
sect2.para: It is strongly advised that the contributor attend a key signing party at an Apache event, in order that other Apache committers/members can in person verify their identity against the key. The process for this is described here and here.

sect2.title: Update Maven Settings file (~/.m2/settings.xml)
sect2.para: The Maven release plugin will automatically sign the release, however it is necessary to update the ~/.m2/settings.xml file with your GPG passphrase in order that it can use your secret key. This is defined under a profile so that it is activated only when we perform a release (as defined by [org,apache:apache] parent POM.
Therefore, make the following
sect2.programlisting: <settings> ... <profiles> <profile> <id>apache-release</id> <properties> <gpg.passphrase>xxx xxx xxx xxx xxx xxx xxx</gpg.passphrase> </properties> </profile> </profiles> </settings>
sect2.para: In addition, to allow the release plugin to tag SVN changes, you must either add in your LDAP username/password or configure .ssh:
sect2.programlisting: <settings> ... <servers> ... <server> <id>apache.releases.https</id> <username>xxxx</username> <password>xxxx</password> </server> </servers> ... </settings>

sect1.title: Preparing a Release (mvn release:prepare)
sect1.para: We recommend creating release candidates from branches, and then the final release from trunk.

sect2.title: Branch (release candidates only)
sect2.para: First, create a branch:
sect2.programlisting: svn mkdir https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/isis/branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating \ -m "branching to create x.x.x-RCn-incubating" svn copy https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/isis/trunk \ https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/isis/branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating/trunk \ -m "copying trunk to branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating"
sect2.para: Now create a workspace for this branch. The easiest approach is to copy trunk and perform an svn switch:
sect2.programlisting:
cd .../trunk # your local workspace for isis/trunk
cd .. mkdir -p branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating cp -R trunk branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating/trunk
cd branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating/trunk svn switch https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/isis/branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating/trunk
sect2.para: Because the release is being performed in a branch, it is then necessary to edit the parent pom.xml in [oai:isis-parent]. Change trunk to branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating/trunk for each of the children of the <scm> tag:
sect2.programlisting: <scm> <connection> scm:svn:http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/isis/branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating/trunk/ </connection> <developerConnection> scm:svn:https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/isis/branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating/trunk/ </developerConnection> <url> http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/isis/branches/x.x.x-RCn-incubating/trunk/ </url> </scm>
sect2.para: The commit the pom.xml file.

sect2.title: Dry run
sect2.para: The release:prepare command updates all POMs, creates a tag. It's common practice to perform a dry run first:
sect2.programlisting: mvn release:clean release:prepare -P apache-release -D dryRun=true
sect2.para: Specify version as 0.x.x-RCn-incubating.
*** more detail required here.

sect2.title: Release Proper
sect2.para: Assuming that the dry run has succeeded, it's time to create the release proper
sect2.programlisting: mvn release:clean release:prepare -P apache-release -D skipTests=true
sect2.para: Specify version as 0.x.x-RCn-incubating.

note.para: If you are in Europe the mvn release:prepare command almost always fails at the last step, with a message like:
note.programlisting: [ERROR] BUILD FAILURE [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ [INFO] Unable to tag SCM Provider message: The svn tag command failed. Command output: svn: No such revision 936951
note.para: This is due to the SVN mirroring in place between Europe and the master in the US. When you make a commit, it isn't immediately available in Europe to svn up to. Just wait 10 secs and repeat the mvn release:prepare command for it to restart where it left off.
If other things go wrong, then mvn release:clean will do most of the cleaning up in the event of failures.

sect2.para: *** more detail required here.
*** check the archetype versions; may need manual tweaking beforehand if doesn't bump versions correctly?

sect2.title: Post-build sanity check
sect2.para: You should end up with artifacts in your local repo with the new version 0.x.x-RCn-incubating. As a sanity check, use the quickstart archetype to generate the application, and make sure that the generated application runs ok.

If you find problems and the release was performed on trunk (rather than a branch) then you may need to revert the changes. The release commands make and commit changes to the project's pom.xml files and they create a tag in SVN; you'll need to revert the pom.xml files and delete the tag from SVN.

sect2.title: Deploying Binaries to Staging Repository (mvn release:perform)
sect2.para: The Apache staging repository lives on the Nexus repository hosted at https://repository.apache.org. The process of uploading will create a staging repository that is associated with the host (IP address) performing the release. Once the repository is staged, the newly created staging repository is "closed" in order to make it available to others.

sect3.title: Perform the Release
sect3.para: The command to stage the release is:

sect3.title: Check the Repository
sect3.para: This will put release artifacts into a newly created staging repository . You will need to log into repository.apache.org to see it.
If nothing appears in a staging repo you should stop here and work out why.
Assuming that the repo has been populated, make a note of its repo id; this is needed for the voting thread (see ).

sect3.para: After checking that the staging repository contains the artifacts that you expect you should close the staging repository. This will make it available so that people can check the release.

sect1.title: Voting
sect1.para: Once the artifacts have been uploaded, you can call a vote. Votes last for 72 hours and require a +3 vote from members. While incubating, this vote should be performed on the isis-dev@incubator.apache.org mailing list, and then repeated on the incubator@apache.org mailing list.

sect2.title: Start voting thread on isis-dev@incubator.a.o
sect2.para: You can use the following boilerplate for the vote on isis-dev.
Use the following subject:
sect2.programlisting: [VOTE] Apache Isis release candidate 0.x.x-RCn-incubating
sect2.para: And use the following body:
sect2.programlisting:
I've staged a release candidate for Apache Isis, namely 0.x.x-RCn-incubating.
The signed source ZIP can be downloaded from my home directory on people.apache.org: * http://people.apache.org/~uuuuuuuu/isis-parent-0.x.x-RCn-incubating-source-release.zip (zip file), and * http://people.apache.org/~uuuuuuuu/isis-parent-0.x.x-RCn-incubating-source-release.zip.asc (signature)
The code has been tagged as tags/0.x.x-RCn-incubating.
In addition, the Maven artifacts have been staged to staging repository on repository.apache.org: * https://repository.apache.org/content/repositories/orgapacheisis-zzz/
The RAT checks have passed (see contributors guide for files that are considered as being excluded).
Please verify the release and cast your vote. The vote will be open for 72 hours.
[ ] +1 [ ] 0 [ ] -1
sect2.para: where:

listitem.para: uuuuuuuu is your Apache LDAP username
zzz is the newly created staging repository, from above.

sect2.title: Other contributors cast their vote
sect2.para: It is the responsibility of other contributors (or any ASF member) to cast their vote on the release. This section provides some guidance on this process.

sect3.para: Download both the ZIP and .ASC files from the location specified in the voting email. To verify that the signature is correct, use:
The ZIP file should then be unpacked.
Once unpacked, it is recommended that voters at a minimum sanity check the contents, as per .
In particular, when building locally, confirm that the versions in your local repository (~/.m2/repository/org/apache/isis) are correct.

sect3.title: Verifying the binary release artifacts
sect3.para: Optionally, voters can verify the binary releases (in the Maven staging repository).
*** more detail required here.

sect3.title: Casting a Vote
sect3.para: When the above checks have been made (and any other checks that the voter thinks is relevant), they should cast a vote by replying to the email thread above.

sect2.title: After the vote
sect2.para: If the vote has been unsuccessful, then address the problems and go again, incrementing the -RCn suffix.
If the vote has been successful, then cut a new release, with no -RCn suffix, and move onto the next step.

note.para: care should be taken to ensure that the new release is based on the same version as the approved release candidate. One way to do this is to ensure that the local copy from which the release is taken is obtained specifying the correct SVN revision.

sect2.title: Start voting thread on incubator@a.o
sect2.para: Once the vote has been approved on isis-dev and a new non-RCn release has been created, then the release process should be performed again on incubator@apache.org.

sect2.title: Release Source Zip
sect2.para: Releasing the source ZIP is a matter of copying the ZIP into the dist directory on people.apache.org.

note.para: There is an alternative and newer approach, namely to check in the release to subversion. At some stage these procedures will be updated to reflcet this newer approach.

sect2.para: Therefore, log onto people.apache.org, and copy the files over:
sect2.programlisting: mkdir /www/www.apache.org/incubator/isis/ cp ~/public_html/isis-parent-x.x.x-incubating-source-release.* /www/www.apache.org/incubator/isis/.

sect2.title: Release Binaries to Maven Central Repo
sect2.para: From the Nexus pages, select the staging repository and select 'release' from the top menu.
This moves the release artifacts into an Apache releases repository, from there they will be automatically moved to the Maven repository.

sect1.title: Manually Deploy the Release Website
sect1.para: The mechanics of deploying the release site is the same as deploying a snapshot site, however there is the complication of deploying from the relevant tags/x.x.x-incubating tag (rather than trunk) as well as ensuring that the released binaries are correctly referenced on the downloads page.
